title: When he joined HICCASP, he was a moderate Democrat. But as a SAG Board member (1946–60) and then as SAG President (1947–51 and 1959) he took a practical as opposed to political view of union activity in the business, which included backing IATSE over the CSU. To be fair, when he testified as a friendly witness before HUAC in 1947, he affirmed a personal distrust and dislike for Communists but nonetheless politely contended that so long as membership was not technically illegal he opposed a Blacklist
